Award.AwardTitle: CDS&E: Regularization Adaption Processes for Multivariate Calibration and Maintenance
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, and the Computational and Data-Enabled Science and Engineering program of the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Professor John Kalivas of the Department of Chemistry at Idaho State University is developing new methods of multivariate calibration. Calibration is a multidisciplinary problem, but in analytical chemistry, it involves forming a quantitative mathematical relationship between an instrumental signal, such as from a hand held near infrared spectrometer, and a property of interest in a sample, such as the pulp content of trees or the amount of the active pharmaceutical ingredient in tablets. A key feature of the new mathematical calibration processes is the ability to include unlabeled data, for instance, spectra of samples without reference values. With unlabeled data, calibration costs and time will be substantially reduced. Another key feature is a mathematical process allowing adaption of a calibration to new measurement conditions with minimal effort, even if unlabeled data is not available. A minimum of four undergraduates from Idaho State University and a Hispanic professor as a Research Opportunity Award from Central New Mexico Community College in Albuquerque will learn state-of-the-art calibration methods and become proficient at performing scientific research including dissemination. Education of undergraduates in these advanced methods prepares them for subsequent scientific professional pursuits.

This project focuses on new regularization processes for multivariate calibration and prediction based on the fundamentals of Tikhonov regularization. The calibration processes allow multiple penalties (tuning parameters) providing flexibility in forming accurate and precise calibrations and mechanisms to adapt a calibration to new conditions. With these regularization methods comes the ability to include unlabeled data, samples without reference values. Because the expensive component in calibration is obtaining reference values, costs in forming and maintaining calibrations can be substantially reduced with unlabeled data. In order to select optimal values for tuning parameters, new fusion ranking methods will be developed and applied. The overall objective is development of computational regularization processes to adapt a calibration to a new domain using multiple tuning parameters, multiple calibration merits, and unlabeled data if it is available. Results from this project will advance the multidisciplinary field of multivariate calibration. For example, process analytical technology for the pharmaceutical and chemical industries, environmental and agriculture monitoring, and medical diagnostics all rely on multivariate calibration. With the improvements being targeted in this project, these diverse fields may well be better equipped to perform and sustain calibrations. Another broader impact of this project is the planned dissemination of the calibration algorithms via the investigators' web sites, allowing newcomers and practitioners direct access.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In analytical chemistry, chemical analysis by calibration deals with forming a mathematical relationship (a model) between instrumental signals (measurements) and quantitative or qualitative analyte specific information. For example, the concentration of the active pharmaceutical ingredient (analyte) in a tablet is quantitative information and authentication of the origin of a food product (analyte), such as where an extra virgin olive oil is from, is qualitative information. A mathematical model is formed with a set of calibration samples containing known reference analyte values with respective measured signals. The model is then used to predict analyte values in new samples. Unfortunately, the model can quickly become non-usable when compositions of new samples deviate from the calibration samples. A similar problem occurs for measured signals due to small changes in instrumental measurement processes. This project developed novel mathematical processes to correct for sample and instrument deviations thereby providing improved accuracies and precision for chemical analysis. Ultimately, the methods will be useful for future hand-held devices such as a smart phone.

The research was accomplished by 13 undergraduates. Some research involved collaboration with a community college professor.  An image is provided with most of the recent group. As a result of their research efforts, all undergraduates have become keenly adept at calibration methods and developed lifelong cognitive research skills to assist them in graduate school and/or their careers.

The project generated seven papers, one book chapter, and 38 national and international meeting presentations mostly by the undergraduates. There are two manuscripts presently submitted to journals and two manuscripts and one book chapter are in preparation with submission expected by the end of 2019. Of the papers and manuscripts, 12 involve mathematical methodology developments and one is on application problems solved by some of the new methods. The book chapter in preparation is application work. Another submitted manuscript not funded by the grant is on an application problem using methods developed through the grant. 

The general project focus was to develop new mathematical solutions to the universal problem of ?domain adaption? where a quantitative calibration model formed for an existing situation (set of sample and measurement conditions) must be adapted (updated) to now work in new conditions. Some examples of adapting the original calibration model to new conditions are: quantitative predictions on different instruments, correctly analyze wheat samples of a different species, or determine the soil organic content of a sample from a new geographical location. A number of adaption methods were created succeeding at these tasks.

Of the new model adaption methods, one allows for ?greener? chemical analysis. In this method, the new analysis samples for which the quantitative analyte information is sought are also used to adapt the original model. In this way, on the fly analysis is possible eliminating costly time consuming and hazards waste forming sample preparations normally required to adapt the model. For example, instrument measurements are generally easy and fast and only this information is need to adapt the model. Such a process makes it possible to eventually have chemical analysis within easy reach of the consumer with a smart phone.

A spinoff project involved starting new work to thoroughly search (data mine) a large collection of calibration samples to pinpoint those samples best matched to new sample conditions. Calibration samples deemed properly matched are then used to form the mathematical model and predict the particular new samples. An image is provided on the searching process. This approach is termed local modeling and offers an alternative to domain adaption in the traditional way. This spinoff project characterizes our current undergraduate research focus.

With the purchase of new computers for the project, the research laboratory facilities have improved. New computer algorithms have been developed and written for variants of domain adaption problems and classification improvements. The codes are freely available from the investigator along with data sets for duplicating published results. Algorithms are also downloadable from the investigator?s a web site.

In summary, the project advanced the knowledge base and understanding of calibration and domain adaption for multiple disciplines. Thus, all parts of society using products and services based on calibration methodologies are directly affected. For example, determining the freshness of fish and other meat and vegetable products are important to the typical consumer. To accomplish these tasks, superior calibration processes are needed.
